subject: Re: [junit] test last
msgSnippet: ... Sure, most of us have to deal with legacy code at some point. Michael Feathers has even written a whole book on the subject. In general, test last is not
messageBody:
On Thu, 23 Sep 2004 10:12:46 -0000, Coolspot714 <coolspot714@...> wrote:
> Hi everybody,
>
> my question concerns a different approach of writing tests. I'm in the
> unfortunate situation of having to write tests for an existing
> application(I haven't been involved in the development).
>
> I found tons of information about test-driven development and
> test-first, but hardly anything about writing tests after the
> application has been developed. Any experiences?

Sure, most of us have to deal with legacy code at some point. Michael
Feathers has even written a whole book on the subject.

In general, test last is not the way to go if you can avoid it -
building the tests first makes sure that the code is inherently
testable out of necessity. That is not always the case if you try to
write the tests last. And when you write the tests first, you can be
sure that they fail when the code is wrong and pretty sure that
passing means the code is correct. If you write them after the fact,
they may pass whether the code works or doesn't.

And if that is not enough for you, consider this: when you use the
tests to drive you development, you actually write them because it is
simply easier and faster to develop that way (for one thing, many of
us TDD practitioners rarely need to use the debugger). When you write
them afterwards, you do so reluctantly, since the *code already works*
- so you don't think you need them.

A simple analogy: have you ever seen a stone arch being built? If not,
can you picture how it must be done? Once all the stones are in place,
they stay there because none of them can fall through the others. But
how do you get them there in the first place? Image trying to hold all
the stones in place simultaneously while you try to get the keystone
set. You would drop a lot of them and get really frustrated. But a
mason first builds a simple wooden form shaped like the interior of
the arch and piles the stones on it. Then he takes it away when they
are in place. Even though he has done this "extra work" of building
the form, it is faster and more reliable to do it that way. It is the
same thing with developer unit tests.
>
> It still isn't determined yet on which level the tests should take
> place. "Real unit-tests" ("test everything that could possibly break")
> would be too much work for the given time(~6 weeks), I guess. So it
> might be more something like acceptance tests.
>
> The SUT is a middleware-API running on an application server, using
> webservices and RMI to get and set customer data from several remote
> databases (lots of getters for about 10mio customers). => no user
> interface/gui etc.
>
> Since we still have to exactly figure out what we want to test, I
> would appreciate some information about whether or not JUnit is the
> right choice in general (alternatives?) and some advices for my "test
> last" approach.
